ratings.question_text: Overall, how would you rate the workload of this course in comparison to other Yale courses you have taken?
What is your overall assessment of this course?
Do you expect to use this class for credit toward your major, or toward a pre-professional program?

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize ECON 110 05 for a fellow student? Would you recommend ECON 110 05 to another student? Why or why not?
comments: Amazing seminar--must take. Professor Kaplan is a pro, and seminars include lots of interesting discussion and are quite edifying. Interesting material. Easily one of the best classes I took in four years at Yale.

Absolutely take it! This class teaches you about and author and a period, but also about methods of research. No matter what you study, professor Kaplan will interest you and draw on your knowledge to benefit the rest of the class.

FREN 355 addresses Postwar France through the lens of Albert Camus. This is explicit. By the end students not only understand the postwar era, but they start to sympathize with Camus as a person. It is slanted, but for good reason, since time has shown Camus to be largely correct. I would recommend this course to anyone who is interested in European History, Colonialism/Anticolonialism, French Literature, the Cold War, 20th Century Philosophy, Race Relations, or Questions of Identity. This makes a perfect elective for anyone of any major.
